publicationStmt.publisher: The Characters that shaped the Silk Road - A Database and Digital Paleography of Tarim

history.provenance: found in Šorčuqduring T III Š 91.25 + 91.26

seg.seg: Carrying a waterskin (?) over his (s)houlder, he [= Araṇemi] behaves like a water bearer. [As a] pledge (?) ....
but you shall oppress your joy/feelings (?)!” Araṇemi speaks: “(Under) your command I am stand(ing)! ...” ....
“Take (the garlands) into the (pa)lace!” || Thereupon, however, the gardener A(ra)ṇemi now ...
.... || In this way from (this) Ṛṣi of royal dignity ...
... he kept seeing ... on the (lea)ves. For the sake of this one ... all trees divine ...
... he speaks to [his] wife: "[My] love! This day has become a glorious one for me, when (I saw?) this man ...
... was for me. Call [hither]! Divine ... have appeared to me, as it were." || There in the palace of king Candramukha ...
after having called ... in (the midst of) the members of council ... There however now the gardener Araṇemi in (the midst) of the best [ministers] ...
... He virtually enthralled (the) que(en’s) mind. (Whichever) were the best foodstuffs before them, this they gave onto him. ...
they speak: “Who may this man be? He is a-bringing garlands here. He is in possession of all virtues. Our lord (can) not (compete with him.) ...
They say, «Who may this man be?»
[Compared] to his virtues he shines. Thereupon ki(ng) Candramukha, sitting on the lion-throne and for this reason (beholding?) the gardener Araṇemi (carrying) ga(rlands) ...
Darauf fragt König Candramukha ... die Minister: "Wer ist jener Mann? ..."
Thereupon king Candramukha asks ... the ministers: "Who is that man? ..."
he [= Candramukha] asks the ministers: “Who is that man? He looks more (dis)tinguished than all [other] people.” || In [the tune] kintarik || Blue-coloured [is] the hair of his head ...

p.note: Often the nasal in gen.pl. endings is missing and incorrect vowels written: ā for a (klātsāt a2, tākāre-ñ b1), ä for a (krentä b3, amācäntä b6), a for ä (warporṣe a2, warpoṣäṃts b2), and ai for e (ke(r)cc(i)yainne b1). While the wrong interchange betwen the a-vowels is maybe simply due to sloppy copying, ai for e may rather be a hypercorrect.

Continues after a gap of indeterminate length, continued on . The translation basically follows 321-2. Araṇemi appears here as a gardener, who is sent to the palace of the king Candramukha with an errand from his master.

Two fragments from the same leaf with a more or less direct joint in line 1 and 6; in line 2 only one akṣaras is completetly missing, in lines 3 and 4 only one, and in line 5 four; the left margin is partly preserved but no leaf number. Large part of the upper layer on the verso side of the right fragment is lost. According to the content, this leaf directly preceds . Therefore, it was probably originally leaf 42 of the manuscript.

If satyakār is the correct word separation, one may derive it from a presupposed Sanskrit form *satyakāra- 'satya-making', which is, however, not attested; to be sure, the phrase satya kṛ- (e.g., satyakriyā- 'oath') means 'to make a pledge, conclude to an agreement'. Accordingly, 321 suggests the translation "Pfand" with question mark.
On the construction war āṣtsiś yakne yamaṣṣäṃ, see 90 and 153, note 4.

warporṣe seems to be a ṣṣe-derivative from the abstract warpor from the root wärpā- (Gv.) which has many different meanings: 'feel; enjoy; suffer; receive; consent'. Note that one would expect wärporṣe; if this is not simply a misspelling, the accent may be analogical to the initially accented abstract warpalñe beside derived warpalñeṣṣe. Note that the PPt warpoṣäṃts made from the same root in b2 also shows incorrect wa.

2.sg.act. klātsāt from kältsā- (Gv.) is a misspelling for either klātsat or klatsāt; but since the full grade in the root rather speaks in favor of an ablauting subjunctive V stem, initial accent in the active singular and accordingly klātsat ought to be the correct form (cf. 286). Note that we have a similar misspelling tākāre-ñ for takāre-ñ in b1.

The sense no doubt is that nature mirrors the presence of Araṇemi such as "he kept seeing (blissfull signs) on the (lea)ves. For the sake of this one ... all trees (showed) divine (bloom/smell vel sim.)". Obl.pl. ñäkci(yeṃ) is also possible.
ke(r)cc(i)yainne for ke(r)cc(i)yenne (correct in a3) may be a hypercorrect form.

If the general calculation about the joint of the two fragments is correct, there is only space for one single missing akṣara (as per Sieg/Siegling). Thomas 245 proposed restoration to s(kwamna) ‘fortune', followed by 322; however, one would expect traces of the complex sign kw to be seen below the s, so this is unlikely even though it would fit the fem.pl. adjective very well. 2.pl. Imp pokkāk(a)s is also possible.

The adjective gen.pl. śpaluwenta(ṃ)ts "among the best" no doubt refers to the members of council, so that one would expect a masculine form, but a gen.pl.masc. from a u-adjective ought to be written śpaluwentäṃts (cf. 155f., § 243-4.)

The 3.sg.mid. Prs Xa klāsträ for källāsträ shows irregular syncope, a characteristics of informal speech. Note that the whole Araṇemi manuscript not so rarely shows informal style characteristics. The hypercorrect 〈ai〉 in b1 fits here as well. Furthermore, eṅwe for eṅkwe.
Thomas 245 correctly points out that there is only space for one single missing akṣara in the lacuna between the two fragments, so only the restoration tswai(ññe) is possible.

list.item: a1 ntsesa watsālai premane war āṣtsiś yakne yama_ṣ_aṃ satyakār [a] /// a2 warporṣe mai klātsā_t(\)• araṇemi we_ṣ_ṣ_aṃ tañ yai[tk]o (– ·)y(·) ñca nes[au] sa /// a3 r(·)iyenne pāsa || om no ñake ○ [a](–)ṇemi werpiśkatse /// a4 (– –) te || [t]e-maṃt yaknesa ○ (–) [laṃtu]ññeṣṣepi rṣāke /// a5 (– –) l(·)āsasa lkāṣṣi cwi perne[sa] (– – – ) – po stāna ñäkci /// a6 (– –) – noś we_ṣ_ṣ_aṃ ṣarya [k]auṃ (·)[ū] (–)rn(·)[w] t(·)kā-ñä\ ente ce śaumo /// b1 (– – –) t[a]kā-ñä\ pokkāk(·)[s](· –) pāk[r]i tākāre-ñ[ä]\ ñäkcyana ram_t\• || tane candramukhi lānte ke(·)cc(·)yainne /// b2 (– –)kkā[k](·)rmeṃ sārri warpo_ṣ_aṃt_s(\) e (– – – – –) [o]m no ñake se araṇemi werpiśkatstse śpaluwentat_s\• yw(·) /// b3 (– –) śānmya ram no palsko la ○ (– –) – cet_s\ kren_t_a śwatsanma enepre tākoyeṃ tuk cwi _p_ast aiṣṣiy[e] /// b4 (·)[w](·)sk·ṃ k_use pi se eṅwe ste tsw[ai] ○ (–) [ta]ne cärkenta klāst_r_a po krentaunasa kekenu ste mā we_s_aṃ saswe /// b5 cwi krentauna_śc\• pa_l_k_aṃ || tumeṃ candra[m]ukh[e] [wa](–) ṣecakecce asānne ṣmemane twār _ṣ[_p]_a araṇemiṃ werpiśkacce cä /// b6 amācän_t_a pre_k_ṣ_aṃ k_use samp eṅwe ste po śāmna[s](· –)[ṣ](·)_p(\) lkātsi ste || kintarikne || rājavat-yo_k\ matsi cwim[_p]\• ///

Often the nasal in gen.pl. endings is missing and incorrect vowels written: ā for a (klātsāt a2, tākāre-ñ b1), ä for a (krentä b3, amācäntä b6), a for ä (warporṣe a2, warpoṣäṃts b2), and ai for e (ke(r)cc(i)yainne b1). While the wrong interchange betwen the a-vowels is maybe simply due to sloppy copying, ai for e may rather be a hypercorrect.

a1 If satyakār is the correct word separation, one may derive it from a presupposed Sanskrit form *satyakāra- 'satya-making', which is, however, not attested; to be sure, the phrase satya kṛ- (e.g., satyakriyā- 'oath') means 'to make a pledge, conclude to an agreement'. Accordingly, [[Schmidt KT 2001]]: 321 suggests the translation "Pfand" with question mark.

a2 warporṣe seems to be a ṣṣe-derivative from the abstract warpor from the root wärpā- (Gv.) which has many different meanings: 'feel; enjoy; suffer; receive; consent'. Note that one would expect wärporṣe; if this is not simply a misspelling, the accent may be analogical to the initially accented abstract warpalñe beside derived warpalñeṣṣe. Note that the PPt warpoṣäṃts made from the same root in b2 also shows incorrect wa.

a2 2.sg.act. klātsāt from kältsā- (Gv.) is a misspelling for either klātsat or klatsāt; but since the full grade in the root rather speaks in favor of an ablauting subjunctive V stem, initial accent in the active singular and accordingly klātsat ought to be the correct form (cf. [[Malzahn 2010]]: 286). Note that we have a similar misspelling tākāre-ñ for takāre-ñ in b1.

b1 ke(r)cc(i)yainne for ke(r)cc(i)yenne (correct in a3) may be a hypercorrect form.

b2 The adjective gen.pl. śpaluwenta(ṃ)ts "among the best" no doubt refers to the members of council, so that one would expect a masculine form, but a gen.pl.masc. from a u-adjective ought to be written śpaluwentäṃts (cf. [[Krause and Thomas, TEB I]]: 155f., § 243-4.)

b4 The 3.sg.mid. Prs Xa klāsträ for källāsträ shows irregular syncope, a characteristics of informal speech. Note that the whole Araṇemi manuscript not so rarely shows informal style characteristics. The hypercorrect 〈ai〉 in b1 fits here as well. Furthermore, eṅwe for eṅkwe.

b6 eṅwe for eṅkwe.

Continues [[THT 90]] after a gap of indeterminate length, continued on [[THT 92]]. The translation basically follows [[Schmidt KT 2001]]: 321-2. Araṇemi appears here as a gardener, who is sent to the palace of the king Candramukha with an errand from his master.

a1 On the construction war āṣtsiś yakne yamaṣṣäṃ, see [[Dietz 1981]]: 90 and 153, note 4.

a5 The sense no doubt is that nature mirrors the presence of Araṇemi such as "he kept seeing (blissfull signs) on the (lea)ves. For the sake of this one ... all trees (showed) divine (bloom/smell vel sim.)". Obl.pl. ñäkci(yeṃ) is also possible.

b1 If the general calculation about the joint of the two fragments is correct, there is only space for one single missing akṣara (as per Sieg/Siegling). Thomas [[TochSprR(B)2]]: 245 proposed restoration to s(kwamna) ‘fortune', followed by [[Schmidt KT 2001]]: 322; however, one would expect traces of the complex sign kw to be seen below the s, so this is unlikely even though it would fit the fem.pl. adjective very well. 2.pl. Imp pokkāk(a)s is also possible.

b4 Thomas [[TochSprR(B)2]]: 245 correctly points out that there is only space for one single missing akṣara in the lacuna between the two fragments, so only the restoration tswai(ññe) is possible.

a1 Carrying a waterskin (?) over his (s)houlder, he [= Araṇemi] behaves like a water bearer. [As a] pledge (?) .... a2 but you shall oppress your joy/feelings (?)!” Araṇemi speaks: “(Under) your command I am stand(ing)! ...” .... a3 “Take (the garlands) into the (pa)lace!” || Thereupon, however, the gardener A(ra)ṇemi now ... a4 .... || In this way from (this) Ṛṣi of royal dignity ... a5 ... he kept seeing ... on the (lea)ves. For the sake of this one ... all trees divine ... a6 ... he speaks to [his] wife: "[My] love! This day has become a glorious one for me, when (I saw?) this man ... b1 ... was for me. Call [hither]! Divine ... have appeared to me, as it were." || There in the palace of king Candramukha ... b2 after having called ... in (the midst of) the members of council ... There however now the gardener Araṇemi in (the midst) of the best [ministers] ... b3 ... He virtually enthralled (the) que(en’s) mind. (Whichever) were the best foodstuffs before them, this they gave onto him. ... b4 they speak: “Who may this man be? He is a-bringing garlands here. He is in possession of all virtues. Our lord (can) not (compete with him.) ... b5 [Compared] to his virtues he shines. Thereupon ki(ng) Candramukha, sitting on the lion-throne and for this reason (beholding?) the gardener Araṇemi (carrying) ga(rlands) ... b6 he [= Candramukha] asks the ministers: “Who is that man? He looks more (dis)tinguished than all [other] people.” || In [the tune] kintarik || Blue-coloured [is] the hair of his head ...

Two fragments from the same leaf with a more or less direct joint in line 1 and 6; in line 2 only one akṣaras is completetly missing, in lines 3 and 4 only one, and in line 5 four; the left margin is partly preserved but no leaf number. Large part of the upper layer on the verso side of the right fragment is lost. According to the content, this leaf directly preceds [[THT 92]]. Therefore, it was probably originally leaf 42 of the manuscript.

Alternative classifications:
Peyrot–
Malzahn–
TamaiII-3 (800-900)
Tamai-C14–
